Journal.Title: Water science and technology : a journal of the International Association on Water Pollution Research

Article.ArticleTitle: Ozonation process intensification of p-nitrophenol by in situ separation of hydroxyl radical scavengers and microbubbles.

AbstractText: The ozonation efficiency for removal of recalcitrant organic pollutants in alkaline wastewater is always low because of the presence of some hydroxyl radical scavengers. To solve this problem, the O<sub>3</sub>/Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> system was put forward, and p-nitrophenol (PNP) was chosen to explore the mechanism of this system. The effects of key operational parameters were studied respectively; the Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> dosage 3 g/L, ozone inlet flow rate 3.5 L/min, ozone concentration 65 mg/L, reactor pressure 0.25 MPa, and temperature 25 °C were obtained as the optimal operating conditions. After 60 min treatment, the organic matter mineralized completely, which was higher than the sum of the ozonation-alone process (55.63%) and the Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> process (3.53%). It suggests that the calcium hydroxide in the O<sub>3</sub>/Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> process possessed a paramount role in the removal of PNP. The liquid samples and the precipitated substances were analyzed by gas chromatography mass spectrometry, X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; it was demonstrated that Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> could accelerate the generation of hydroxyl radical and simultaneously in situ separate partial intermediate products and CO<sub>3</sub> <sup>2-</sup> ions through some precipitation reactions.
